SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Grandam, his nurse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Pitchers have ears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes a messenger. What news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: How fares the prince?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Well, madam, and in health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: What is thy news then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,
With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Who hath committed them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: The mighty dukes
Gloucester and Buckingham.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: For what offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed;
Why or for what these nobles were committed
Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house!
The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind;
Insulting tyranny begins to jet
Upon the innocent and aweless throne:
Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!
I see, as in a map, the end of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days,
How many of you have mine eyes beheld!
My husband lost his life to get the crown;
And often up and down my sons were toss'd,
For me to joy and weep their gain and loss:
And being seated, and domestic broils
Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors.
Make war upon themselves; blood against blood,
Self against self: O, preposterous
And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen;
Or let me die, to look on death no more!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary.
Madam, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I'll go along with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: You have no cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious lady, go;
And thither bear your treasure and your goods.
For my part, I'll resign unto your grace
The seal I keep: and so betide to me
As well I tender you and all of yours!
Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. London. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, CARDINAL, CATESBY, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign
The weary way hath made you melancholy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: No, uncle; but our crosses on the way
Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy
I want more uncles here to welcome me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years
Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit
Nor more can you distinguish of a man
Than of his outward show; which, God he knows,
Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.
Those uncles which you want were dangerous;
Your grace attended to their sugar'd words,
But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :
God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Lord Mayor and his train

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: God bless your grace with health and happy days!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.
I thought my mother, and my brother York,
Would long ere this have met us on the way
Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not
To tell us whether they will come or no!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: On what occasion, God he knows, not I,
The queen your mother, and your brother York,
Have taken sanctuary: the tender prince
Would fain have come with me to meet your grace,
But by his mother was perforce withheld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace
Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York
Unto his princely brother presently?
If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,
And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CARDINAL
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory
Can from his mother win the Duke of York,
Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord,
Too ceremonious and traditional
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,
You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place,
And those who have the wit to claim the place:
This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;
And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:
Then, taking him from thence that is not there,
You break no privilege nor charter there.
Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;
But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CARDINAL
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.
Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I go, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,
Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Where it seems best unto your royal self.
If I may counsel you, some day or two
Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:
Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit
For your best health and recreation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: I do not like the Tower, of any place.
Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;
Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Is it upon record, or else reported
Successively from age to age, he built it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Upon record, my gracious lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: But say, my lord, it were not register'd,
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,
Even to the general all-ending day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside So wise so young, they say, do never
live long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: What say you, uncle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I say, without characters, fame lives long.
Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,
I moralize two meanings in one word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: That Julius Caesar was a famous man;
With what his valour did enrich his wit,
His wit set down to make his valour live
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;
For now he lives in fame, though not in life.
I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: What, my gracious lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: An if I live until I be a man,
I'll win our ancient right in France again,
Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:
Too late he died that might have kept that title,
Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,
You said that idle weeds are fast in growth
The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: He hath, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: And therefore is he idle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: He may command me as my sovereign;
But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: A beggar, brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;
And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;
In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:
Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:
Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;
Because that I am little, like an ape,
He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!
To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,
He prettily and aptly taunts himself:
So cunning and so young is wonderful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, will't please you pass along?
Myself and my good cousin Buckingham
Will to your mother, to entreat of her
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: My lord protector needs will have it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what should you fear?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:
My grandam told me he was murdered there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: I fear no uncles dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Nor none that live, I hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE EDWARD
SPEECH.LINE: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,
Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A Sennet. Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM and CATESBY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Think you, my lord, this little prating York
Was not incensed by his subtle mother
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy;
Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable
He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend
As closely to conceal what we impart:
Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;
What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter
To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,
For the instalment of this noble duke
In the seat royal of this famous isle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: He for his father's sake so loves the prince,
That he will not be won to aught against him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,
And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,
How doth he stand affected to our purpose;
And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,
To sit about the coronation.
If thou dost find him tractable to us,
Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:
If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,
Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,
And give us notice of his inclination:
For we to-morrow hold divided councils,
Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,
His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries
To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;
And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,
Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: You shall, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive
Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:
And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me
The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables
Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And look to have it yielded with all willingness.
Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards
We may digest our complots in some form.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Before Lord Hastings' house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: What, ho! my lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Within Who knocks at the door?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: A messenger from the Lord Stanley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: What is't o'clock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Upon the stroke of four.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: So it should seem by that I have to say.
First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: And then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: And then he sends you word
He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm:
Besides, he says there are two councils held;
And that may be determined at the one
which may make you and him to rue at the other.
Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure,
If presently you will take horse with him,
And with all speed post with him toward the north,
To shun the danger that his soul divines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;
Bid him not fear the separated councils
His honour and myself are at the one,
And at the other is my servant Catesby
Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us
Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance:
And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fond
To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers
To fly the boar before the boar pursues,
Were to incense the boar to follow us
And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
Go, bid thy master rise and come to me
And we will both together to the Tower,
Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring
What news, what news, in this our tottering state?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord;
And I believe twill never stand upright
Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders
Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.
But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward
Upon his party for the gain thereof:
And thereupon he sends you this good news,
That this same very day your enemies,
The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,
Because they have been still mine enemies:
But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side,
To bar my master's heirs in true descent,
God knows I will not do it, to the death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,
That they who brought me in my master's hate
I live to look upon their tragedy.
I tell thee, Catesby--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: What, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Ere a fortnight make me elder,
I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,
When men are unprepared and look not for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out
With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do
With some men else, who think themselves as safe
As thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dear
To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: The princes both make high account of you;
For they account his head upon the bridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I know they do; and I have well deserved it.
Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man?
Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby:
You may jest on, but, by the holy rood,
I do not like these several councils, I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: My lord,
I hold my life as dear as you do yours;
And never in my life, I do protest,
Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:
Think you, but that I know our state secure,
I would be so triumphant as I am?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,
Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure,
And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;
But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.
This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt:
Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord?
To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LORD STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads
Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
But come, my lord, let us away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.
How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pursuivant
SPEECH.LINE: The better that your lordship please to ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now
Than when I met thee last where now we meet:
Then was I going prisoner to the Tower,
By the suggestion of the queen's allies;
But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself--
This day those enemies are put to death,
And I in better state than e'er I was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pursuivant
SPEECH.LINE: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pursuivant
SPEECH.LINE: God save your lordship!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Priest
SPEECH.LINE: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.
I am in your debt for your last exercise;
Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain?
Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest;
Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,
Those men you talk of came into my mind.
What, go you toward the Tower?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay
I shall return before your lordship thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Aside And supper too, although thou know'st it not.
Come, will you go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I'll wait upon your lordship.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Pomfret Castle.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter RATCLIFF, with halberds, carrying RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN to death

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RATCLIFF
SPEECH.LINE: Come, bring forth the prisoners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this:
To-day shalt thou behold a subject die
For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREY
SPEECH.LINE: God keep the prince from all the pack of you!
A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VAUGHAN
SPEECH.LINE: You live that shall cry woe for this after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RATCLIFF
SPEECH.LINE: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,
Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
Within the guilty closure of thy walls
Richard the second here was hack'd to death;
And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,
We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREY
SPEECH.LINE: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads,
For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham,
Then cursed she Richard. O, remember, God
To hear her prayers for them, as now for us
And for my sister and her princely sons,
Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,
Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RATCLIFF
SPEECH.LINE: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RIVERS
SPEECH.LINE: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace:
And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. The Tower of London.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, the BISHOP OF ELY, RATCLIFF, LOVEL, with others, and take their seats at a table

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: My lords, at once: the cause why we are met
Is, to determine of the coronation.
In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Are all things fitting for that royal time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DERBY
SPEECH.LINE: It is, and wants but nomination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?
Who is most inward with the royal duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces,
But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine,
Than I of yours;
Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.
Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well;
But, for his purpose in the coronation.
I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd
His gracious pleasure any way therein:
But you, my noble lords, may name the time;
And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice,
Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope,
My absence doth neglect no great designs,
Which by my presence might have been concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Had not you come upon your cue, my lord
William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,--
I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;
His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: I thank your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord of Ely!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: When I was last in Holborn,
I saw good strawberries in your garden there
I do beseech you send for some of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business,
And finds the testy gentleman so hot,
As he will lose his head ere give consent
His master's son, as worshipful as he terms it,
Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DERBY
SPEECH.LINE: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;
For I myself am not so well provided
As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF ELY
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these
strawberries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day;
There's some conceit or other likes him well,
When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.
I think there's never a man in Christendom
That can less hide his love or hate than he;
For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DERBY
SPEECH.LINE: What of his heart perceive you in his face
By any likelihood he show'd to-day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, that with no man here he is offended;
For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DERBY
SPEECH.LINE: I pray God he be not, I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve
That do conspire my death with devilish plots
Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd
Upon my body with their hellish charms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord,
Makes me most forward in this noble presence
To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be
I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:
See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm
Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:
And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch,
Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,
That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet--
Tellest thou me of 'ifs'? Thou art a traitor:
Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear,
I will not dine until I see the same.
Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done:
The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but HASTINGS, RATCLIFF, and LOVEL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me;
For I, too fond, might have prevented this.
Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;
But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:
Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,
And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower,
As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.
O, now I want the priest that spake to me:
I now repent I told the pursuivant
As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies,
How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,
And I myself secure in grace and favour.
O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse
Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RATCLIFF
SPEECH.LINE: Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:
Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: O momentary grace of mortal men,
Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks,
Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,
Ready, with every nod, to tumble down
Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LOVEL
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HASTINGS
SPEECH.LINE: O bloody Richard! miserable England!
I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee
That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.
Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.
They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. The Tower-walls.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, in rotten armour, marvellous ill-favoured

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour,
Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,
And then begin again, and stop again,
As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian;
Speak and look back, and pry on every side,
Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,
Intending deep suspicion: ghastly looks
Are at my service, like enforced smiles;
And both are ready in their offices,
At any time, to grace my stratagems.
But what, is Catesby gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Lord Mayor and CATESBY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Lord mayor,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Look to the drawbridge there!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Hark! a drum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: God and our innocency defend and guard us!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter LOVEL and RATCLIFF, with HASTINGS' head

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LOVEL
SPEECH.LINE: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,
The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: So dear I loved the man, that I must weep.
I took him for the plainest harmless creature
That breathed upon this earth a Christian;
Made him my book wherein my soul recorded
The history of all her secret thoughts:
So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue,
That, his apparent open guilt omitted,
I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife,
He lived from all attainder of suspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor
That ever lived.
Would you imagine, or almost believe,
Were't not that, by great preservation,
We live to tell it you, the subtle traitor
This day had plotted, in the council-house
To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: What, had he so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: What, think You we are Turks or infidels?
Or that we would, against the form of law,
Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death,
But that the extreme peril of the case,
The peace of England and our persons' safety,
Enforced us to this execution?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Now, fair befall you! he deserved his death;
And you my good lords, both have well proceeded,
To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
I never look'd for better at his hands,
After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Yet had not we determined he should die,
Until your lordship came to see his death;
Which now the loving haste of these our friends,
Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:
Because, my lord, we would have had you heard
The traitor speak, and timorously confess
The manner and the purpose of his treason;
That you might well have signified the same
Unto the citizens, who haply may
Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: But, my good lord, your grace's word shall serve,
As well as I had seen and heard him speak
And doubt you not, right noble princes both,
But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens
With all your just proceedings in this cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here,
To avoid the carping censures of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: But since you come too late of our intents,
Yet witness what you hear we did intend:
And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.
The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:
There, at your meet'st advantage of the time,
Infer the bastardy of Edward's children:
Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen,
Only for saying he would make his son
Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house,
Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.
Moreover, urge his hateful luxury
And bestial appetite in change of lust;
Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,
Even where his lustful eye or savage heart,
Without control, listed to make his prey.
Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:
Tell them, when that my mother went with child
Of that unsatiate Edward, noble York
My princely father then had wars in France
And, by just computation of the time,
Found that the issue was not his begot;
Which well appeared in his lineaments,
Being nothing like the noble duke my father:
But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off,
Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator
As if the golden fee for which I plead
Were for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle;
Where you shall find me well accompanied
With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I go: and towards three or four o'clock
Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw;
Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both
Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.
Now will I in, to take some privy order,
To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight;
And to give notice, that no manner of person
At any time have recourse unto the princes.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. The same.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Scrivener, with a paper in his hand

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scrivener
SPEECH.LINE: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;
Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd,
That it may be this day read over in Paul's.
And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven hours I spent to write it over,
For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me;
The precedent was full as long a-doing:
And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings,
Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty
Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross,
That seeth not this palpable device?
Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?
Bad is the world; and all will come to nought,
When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VII. Baynard's Castle.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, at several doors

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,
The citizens are mum and speak not a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy,
And his contract by deputy in France;
The insatiate greediness of his desires,
And his enforcement of the city wives;
His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,
As being got, your father then in France,
His resemblance, being not like the duke;
Withal I did infer your lineaments,
Being the right idea of your father,
Both in your form and nobleness of mind;
Laid open all your victories in Scotland,
Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace,
Your bounty, virtue, fair humility:
Indeed, left nothing fitting for the purpose
Untouch'd, or slightly handled, in discourse
And when mine oratory grew to an end
I bid them that did love their country's good
Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Ah! and did they so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: No, so God help me, they spake not a word;
But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.
Which when I saw, I reprehended them;
And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence:
His answer was, the people were not wont
To be spoke to but by the recorder.
Then he was urged to tell my tale again,
'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;'
But nothing spake in warrant from himself.
When he had done, some followers of mine own,
At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps,
And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!'
And thus I took the vantage of those few,
'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I;
'This general applause and loving shout
Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:'
And even here brake off, and came away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: No, by my troth, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear;
Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit:
And look you get a prayer-book in your hand,
And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord;
For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:
And be not easily won to our request:
Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I go; and if you plead as well for them
As I can say nay to thee for myself,
No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter the Lord Mayor and Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here;
I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby,
What says he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord: he doth entreat your grace;
To visit him to-morrow or next day:
He is within, with two right reverend fathers,
Divinely bent to meditation;
And no worldly suit would he be moved,
To draw him from his holy exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;
Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens,
In deep designs and matters of great moment,
No less importing than our general good,
Are come to have some conference with his grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: I'll tell him what you say, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!
He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed,
But on his knees at meditation;
Not dallying with a brace of courtezans,
But meditating with two deep divines;
Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,
But praying, to enrich his watchful soul:
Happy were England, would this gracious prince
Take on himself the sovereignty thereof:
But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I fear he will.
How now, Catesby, what says your lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord,
He wonders to what end you have assembled
Such troops of citizens to speak with him,
His grace not being warn'd thereof before:
My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Sorry I am my noble cousin should
Suspect me, that I mean no good to him:
By heaven, I come in perfect love to him;
And so once more return and tell his grace.
When holy and devout religious men
Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence,
So sweet is zealous contemplation.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter GLOUCESTER aloft, between two Bishops. CATESBY returns

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: See, where he stands between two clergymen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,
To stay him from the fall of vanity:
And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,
True ornaments to know a holy man.
Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,
Lend favourable ears to our request;
And pardon us the interruption
Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, there needs no such apology:
I rather do beseech you pardon me,
Who, earnest in the service of my God,
Neglect the visitation of my friends.
But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above,
And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I do suspect I have done some offence
That seems disgracious in the city's eyes,
And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: You have, my lord: would it might please your grace,
At our entreaties, to amend that fault!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Then know, it is your fault that you resign
The supreme seat, the throne majestical,
The scepter'd office of your ancestors,
Your state of fortune and your due of birth,
The lineal glory of your royal house,
To the corruption of a blemished stock:
Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,
Which here we waken to our country's good,
This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;
Her face defaced with scars of infamy,
Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,
And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf
Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.
Which to recure, we heartily solicit
Your gracious self to take on you the charge
And kingly government of this your land,
Not as protector, steward, substitute,
Or lowly factor for another's gain;
But as successively from blood to blood,
Your right of birth, your empery, your own.
For this, consorted with the citizens,
Your very worshipful and loving friends,
And by their vehement instigation,
In this just suit come I to move your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I know not whether to depart in silence,
Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.
Best fitteth my degree or your condition
If not to answer, you might haply think
Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,
Which fondly you would here impose on me;
If to reprove you for this suit of yours,
So season'd with your faithful love to me.
Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends.
Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,
And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,
Definitively thus I answer you.
Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert
Unmeritable shuns your high request.
First if all obstacles were cut away,
And that my path were even to the crown,
As my ripe revenue and due by birth
Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,
So mighty and so many my defects,
As I had rather hide me from my greatness,
Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,
Than in my greatness covet to be hid,
And in the vapour of my glory smother'd.
But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me,
And much I need to help you, if need were;
The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,
Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time,
Will well become the seat of majesty,
And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
On him I lay what you would lay on me,
The right and fortune of his happy stars;
Which God defend that I should wring from him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, this argues conscience in your grace;
But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,
All circumstances well considered.
You say that Edward is your brother's son:
So say we too, but not by Edward's wife;
For first he was contract to Lady Lucy--
Your mother lives a witness to that vow--
And afterward by substitute betroth'd
To Bona, sister to the King of France.
These both put by a poor petitioner,
A care-crazed mother of a many children,
A beauty-waning and distressed widow,
Even in the afternoon of her best days,
Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye,
Seduced the pitch and height of all his thoughts
To base declension and loathed bigamy
By her, in his unlawful bed, he got
This Edward, whom our manners term the prince.
More bitterly could I expostulate,
Save that, for reverence to some alive,
I give a sparing limit to my tongue.
Then, good my lord, take to your royal self
This proffer'd benefit of dignity;
If non to bless us and the land withal,
Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry
From the corruption of abusing times,
Unto a lineal true-derived course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, why would you heap these cares on me?
I am unfit for state and majesty;
I do beseech you, take it not amiss;
I cannot nor I will not yield to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: If you refuse it,--as, in love and zeal,
Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son;
As well we know your tenderness of heart
And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,
Which we have noted in you to your kin,
And egally indeed to all estates,--
Yet whether you accept our suit or no,
Your brother's son shall never reign our king;
But we will plant some other in the throne,
To the disgrace and downfall of your house:
And in this resolution here we leave you.--
Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANOTHER
SPEECH.LINE: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Would you enforce me to a world of care?
Well, call them again. I am not made of stone,
But penetrable to your. kind entreats,
Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men,
Since you will buckle fortune on my back,
To bear her burthen, whether I will or no,
I must have patience to endure the load:
But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach
Attend the sequel of your imposition,
Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me
From all the impure blots and stains thereof;
For God he knows, and you may partly see,
How far I am from the desire thereof.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Then I salute you with this kingly title:
Long live Richard, England's royal king!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord Mayor
Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Even when you please, since you will have it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace:
And so most joyfully we take our leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let us to our holy task again.
Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Before the Tower.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, on one side, QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS OF YORK, and DORSET; on the other, ANNE, Duchess of Gloucester, leading Lady Margaret Plantagenet, CLARENCE's young Daughter

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Who meets us here? my niece Plantagenet
Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower,
On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.
Daughter, well met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: God give your graces both
A happy and a joyful time of day!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,
Upon the like devotion as yourselves,
To gratulate the gentle princes there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.
And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.
Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,
How doth the prince, and my young son of York?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRAKENBURY
SPEECH.LINE: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,
I may not suffer you to visit them;
The king hath straitly charged the contrary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: The king! why, who's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRAKENBURY
SPEECH.LINE: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?
I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother:
Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame
And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRAKENBURY
SPEECH.LINE: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so:
I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LORD STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence,
And I'll salute your grace of York as mother,
And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.
Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,
There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart
May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon
With this dead-killing news!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DORSET
SPEECH.LINE: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!
Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;
Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas,
And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell
Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,
Lest thou increase the number of the dead;
And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse,
Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LORD STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.
Take all the swift advantage of the hours;
You shall have letters from me to my son
To meet you on the way, and welcome you.
Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
O my accursed womb, the bed of death!
A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world,
Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LORD STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: And I in all unwillingness will go.
I would to God that the inclusive verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!
Anointed let me be with deadly venom,
And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory
To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: No! why? When he that is my husband now
Came to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse,
When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands
Which issued from my other angel husband
And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;
O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face,
This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed,
For making me, so young, so old a widow!
And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;
And be thy wife--if any be so mad--
As miserable by the life of thee
As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!
Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,
Even in so short a space, my woman's heart
Grossly grew captive to his honey words
And proved the subject of my own soul's curse,
Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest;
For never yet one hour in his bed
Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep,
But have been waked by his timorous dreams.
Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;
And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY ANNE
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, poor soul, that takest thy leave of it!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee!
Go thou to Richard, and good angels guard thee!
Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee!
I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me!
Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen,
And each hour's joy wrecked with a week of teen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.
Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes
Whom envy hath immured within your walls!
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow
For tender princes, use my babies well!
So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. London. The palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III, in pomp, crowned; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a page, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious sovereign?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Give me thy hand.
Thus high, by thy advice
And thy assistance, is King Richard seated;
But shall we wear these honours for a day?
Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Still live they and for ever may they last!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch,
To try if thou be current gold indeed
Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Say on, my loving lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: True, noble prince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: O bitter consequence,
That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!'
Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;
And I would have it suddenly perform'd.
What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Your grace may do your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth:
Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord
Before I positively herein:
I will resolve your grace immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: The king is angry: see, he bites the lip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: I will converse with iron-witted fools
And unrespective boys: none are for me
That look into me with considerate eyes:
High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.
Boy!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page
SPEECH.LINE: My lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold
Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,
Whose humble means match not his haughty mind:
Gold were as good as twenty orators,
And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: What is his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page
SPEECH.LINE: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: I partly know the man: go, call him hither.
The deep-revolving witty Buckingham
No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:
Hath he so long held out with me untired,
And stops he now for breath?
How now! what news with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: STANLEY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled
To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea
Where he abides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Catesby!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Rumour it abroad
That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die:
I will take order for her keeping close.
Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman,
Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:
The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.
Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out
That Anne my wife is sick and like to die:
About it; for it stands me much upon,
To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
I must be married to my brother's daughter,
Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
Murder her brothers, and then marry her!
Uncertain way of gain! But I am in
So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:
Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
Is thy name Tyrrel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou, indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my lord;
But I had rather kill two enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies,
Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers
Are they that I would have thee deal upon:
Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: Let me have open means to come to them,
And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel
Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:
There is no more but so: say it is done,
And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: Ye shall, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind
The late demand that you did sound me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I hear that news, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,
For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;
The earldom of Hereford and the moveables
The which you promised I should possess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey
Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: What says your highness to my just demand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: As I remember, Henry the Sixth
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: How chance the prophet could not at that time
Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,
The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle,
And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started,
Because a bard of Ireland told me once
I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, what's o'clock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind
Of what you promised me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Well, but what's o'clock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Upon the stroke of ten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let it strike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Why let it strike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke
Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
I am not in the giving vein to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, tut,
Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUCKINGHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Is it even so? rewards he my true service
With such deep contempt made I him king for this?
O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.
The most arch of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn
To do this ruthless piece of butchery,
Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs,
Melting with tenderness and kind compassion
Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.
'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:'
'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another
Within their innocent alabaster arms:
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,
Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.
A book of prayers on their pillow lay;
Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;
But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd
Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered
The most replenished sweet work of nature,
That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'
Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both,
To bring this tidings to the bloody king.
And here he comes.
All hail, my sovereign liege!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: If to have done the thing you gave in charge
Beget your happiness, be happy then,
For it is done, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: But didst thou see them dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: I did, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYRREL
SPEECH.LINE: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;
But how or in what place I do not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper,
And thou shalt tell the process of their death.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,
And be inheritor of thy desire.
Farewell till soon.
The son of Clarence have I pent up close;
His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;
The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,
And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims
At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,
And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,
To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: My lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CATESBY
SPEECH.LINE: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond;
And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen,
Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army.
Come, I have heard that fearful commenting
Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary
Then fiery expedition be my wing,
Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!
Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Before the palace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: So, now prosperity begins to mellow
And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd,
To watch the waning of mine adversaries.
A dire induction am I witness to,
And will to France, hoping the consequence
Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and the DUCHESS OF YORK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes!
My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!
If yet your gentle souls fly in the air
And be not fix'd in doom perpetual,
Hover about me with your airy wings
And hear your mother's lamentation!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Hover about her; say, that right for right
Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: So many miseries have crazed my voice,
That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb,
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs,
And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!
Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.
O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: If ancient sorrow be most reverend,
Give mine the benefit of seniory,
And let my woes frown on the upper hand.
If sorrow can admit society,
Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:
I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;
I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him:
Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;
Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;
I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:
That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,
To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,
That foul defacer of God's handiwork,
That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,
That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls,
Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.
O upright, just, and true-disposing God,
How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur
Preys on the issue of his mother's body,
And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!
God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:
Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
Young York he is but boot, because both they
Match not the high perfection of my loss:
Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
And the beholders of this tragic play,
The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,
Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.
Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer,
Only reserved their factor, to buy souls
And send them thither: but at hand, at hand,
Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:
Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.
To have him suddenly convey'd away.
Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey,
That I may live to say, The dog is dead!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune;
I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen;
The presentation of but what I was;
The flattering index of a direful pageant;
One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below;
A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;
A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble,
A sign of dignity, a garish flag,
To be the aim of every dangerous shot,
A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
Where is thy husband now? where be thy brothers?
Where are thy children? wherein dost thou, joy?
Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'?
Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?
Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee?
Decline all this, and see what now thou art:
For happy wife, a most distressed widow;
For joyful mother, one that wails the name;
For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;
For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;
For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;
For one commanding all, obey'd of none.
Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about,
And left thee but a very prey to time;
Having no more but thought of what thou wert,
To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not
Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke;
From which even here I slip my weary neck,
And leave the burthen of it all on thee.
Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:
These English woes will make me smile in France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;
Compare dead happiness with living woe;
Think that thy babes were fairer than they were,
And he that slew them fouler than he is:
Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse:
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN MARGARET
SPEECH.LINE: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Why should calamity be full of words?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Windy attorneys to their client woes,
Airy succeeders of intestate joys,
Poor breathing orators of miseries!
Let them have scope: though what they do impart
Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me.
And in the breath of bitter words let's smother
My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.
I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter KING RICHARD III, marching, with drums and trumpets

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Who intercepts my expedition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: O, she that might have intercepted thee,
By strangling thee in her accursed womb
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown,
Where should be graven, if that right were right,
The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown,
And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?
Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums!
Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women
Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!
Either be patient, and entreat me fair,
Or with the clamorous report of war
Thus will I drown your exclamations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou my son?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Then patiently hear my impatience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: O, let me speak!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Do then: but I'll not hear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee,
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: And came I not at last to comfort you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well,
Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.
A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,
Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,
treacherous,
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred:
What comfortable hour canst thou name,
That ever graced me in thy company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd
your grace
To breakfast once forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your sight,
Let me march on, and not offend your grace.
Strike the drum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee, hear me speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: You speak too bitterly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me a word;
For I shall never speak to thee again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: So.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DUCHESS OF YORK
SPEECH.LINE: Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
And never look upon thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;
Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more
Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Abides in me; I say amen to all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard,
They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens;
And therefore level not to hit their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth,
Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: And must she die for this? O, let her live,
And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty;
Slander myself as false to Edward's bed;
Throw over her the veil of infamy:
So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter,
I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Her life is only safest in her birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: And only in that safety died her brothers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: True, when avoided grace makes destiny:
My babes were destined to a fairer death,
If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts,
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:
No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,
To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,
My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys
Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
And I, in such a desperate bay of death,
Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft,
Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise
And dangerous success of bloody wars,
As I intend more good to you and yours,
Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: What good is cover'd with the face of heaven,
To be discover'd, that can do me good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: No, to the dignity and height of honour
The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Flatter my sorrows with report of it;
Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour,
Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,
Will I withal endow a child of thine;
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindness
Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING RICHARD III
SPEECH.LINE: What do you think?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: QUEEN ELIZABETH
SPEECH.LINE: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul:
So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers;
And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.
